multimedia.caption: Improved Flying

docs.abstract: Joe Starkey On the Road column on survey by Carlson Wagonlit Travel which found that business travelers are most annoyed by airline passengers who stow bulky suitcases, which should have been checked, in overhead space well forward of their seats to allow for quick exit; finds that frustration is often compounded by increasing use of smaller regional jets that typically have 50 or fewer seats; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: WHAT do business travelers say is the most annoying thing about flying? I realize there are hundreds of plausible answers. But the top peeve, according to a survey by Carlson Wagonlit Travel, is a passenger who lumbers on board with a bulky suitca...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT do business travelers say is the most annoying thing about flying? I realize there are hundreds of plausible answers. But the top peeve, according to a survey by Carlson Wagonlit Travel, is a passenger who lumbers on board with a bulky suitcase that you, of course, would have had the courtesy to check. The annoyance is aggravated when that person decides to stow the bag in an overhead bin well forward of his or her seat to allow for a quick getaway, unmindful that overhead space is supposed to be used by the passengers sitting closest to it.

headline.main: No Room for the Passengers, Never Mind the Carry-Ons

docs.abstract: Travel Industry Association of America says of 163 million business trips taken in 2003, 10 percent included children; figure has grown steadily in large part because more women hold high-profile jobs that require travel; some mothers comment on experience of traveling with young child; photo (M)/
docs.snippet: As more women hold high-profile jobs that require travel, they are finding ways to bring their children on business trips....
docs.lead_paragraph: Alana K. Bassin, a partner at Bowman & Brooke, a products-liability law firm in Minneapolis, has a simple checklist for her business travels: a suitcase for her business suits, an attaché case for her legal papers and an infant seat for her daughter, Talia. Just over a year ago, when Talia was 7 months old, Ms. Bassin brought her to a two-week trial in Galveston, Tex., so that she could stick to her nursing schedule. Since then, the pair has hit the road several times, and Ms. Bassin, who is about to give birth for a second time, plans to bring both children on business trips in the future.

headline.main: The Pacifier Isn't for the Client

docs.abstract: Rich are becoming own niche in ever more fragmented media world, with some five percent of 6,200 magazine titles published for general public in United States aimed at wealthy and more entering field; Sidney Frank, who recently entered luxury magazine business by buying Travel Savvy magazine, comments, phone interview; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Luxury magazines that target affluent readers are proliferating, and they make up 5 percent of total magazine publications....
docs.lead_paragraph: Sidney Frank, the liquor baron who recently sold Grey Goose vodka to Bacardi for $2 billion, was just back from Hawaii, where he had bought a house -- his sixth -- for $12.5 million. ''I am on a quest for the best,'' he said by telephone from another of his homes in Southern California. He said that his search applied both to his personal life and his decision to start a new luxury magazine. ''I want a magazine for my lifestyle and other lifestyles like mine.''

headline.main: A Flood of Magazines for Those Awash in Cash

docs.abstract: Avalon Travel publishes new Moon Metro guide series which features fold-out views of neighborhoods and indexes of attractions, restaurants, hotels and shops; Hagstrom publishes its first large-type New York City Five Borough Atlas (M)
docs.snippet: Two new products, a guidebook series and a familiar atlas, have been designed to make city maps easier to use.    The Moon Metro guide, published by Avalon Travel, offers generous overviews of neighborhoods by having facing pages fold out to creat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two new products, a guidebook series and a familiar atlas, have been designed to make city maps easier to use. The Moon Metro guide, published by Avalon Travel, offers generous overviews of neighborhoods by having facing pages fold out to create a map of the area. The neighborhood maps have indexes showing the main attractions and restaurants, hotels and shops, mostly of the upscale variety but with a few budget choices.

keywords.value: HAGSTROM NEW YORK CITY FIVE BOROUGH ATLAS (BOOK)
keywords.name: creative_works

headline.main: Pointing the Way To Easier Map Use

docs.abstract: National Business Travel Association says that as business travel starts to pick up, some regular travelers have been reluctant to fly because of confusion about airport security procedures for use of electronic tickets; problem began few days after terrorist attacks when airports reopened with tighter security measures, including blocking from inner terminals eveyone except those passengers with tickets; to pass through security, holder of e-ticket needs to show printed itinerary, or receipt, from airline or travel agency or online travel site (M)
docs.snippet: As business travel starts to pick up, some regular travelers have been reluctant to fly because of confusion about airport security procedures for the use of electronic tickets, the National Business Travel Association said yesterday.    ''There a...
docs.lead_paragraph: As business travel starts to pick up, some regular travelers have been reluctant to fly because of confusion about airport security procedures for the use of electronic tickets, the National Business Travel Association said yesterday. ''There are a couple of things that have been keeping some business travelers away,'' said Marianne McInerney, the executive director of the association, which represents about 2,000 corporate travel managers. One hurdle is overall concern about security, she said. But a more specific obstacle, she added, is ''what they are perceiving to be the hassle factor'' in using e-tickets, which now account for more than two-thirds of the tickets that airlines issue to business.

headline.main: Business Travelers Balk at 'Hassle Factor' on Electronic Tickets

docs.abstract: Corporate travel-policy consultant Mark Walton says travel cutbacks vary by industry; National Business Travel Association reports 68 percent of major companies surveyed say they are cutting number of employees who travel on business, with nearly half predicting travel curbs will remain in effect through end of year; United States companies seem most affected by cutbacks, which are barely touching business travel in Europe and Asia (M)
docs.snippet: LAST summer, at the National Business Travel Association convention in Los Angeles, Mark Walton, a travel-policy consultant, began a speech with selections from a parody corporate travel department memo that a client had sent to him.    ''Airline ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAST summer, at the National Business Travel Association convention in Los Angeles, Mark Walton, a travel-policy consultant, began a speech with selections from a parody corporate travel department memo that a client had sent to him. ''Airline tickets will be authorized only if purchased in extreme circumstances,'' Mr. Walton read in a flat Midwestern monotone that made him sound like the comedian Bob Newhart. ''Hitchhiking is strictly encouraged. Luminescent safety vests will be issued to all employees prior to their departure.''

keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

headline.main: Business Travel; Don't look now, corporate travelers, but hitchhiking might become a viable option.

docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column disputes assertions by supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton that decision by independent counsel Robert Ray not to indict her in so-called Travelgate affair was form of exoneration; says Clinton is habitual prevaricator (M)
docs.snippet: Remember all the claims by Hillary Clinton's see-no-evil supporters that the decision by independent counsel Robert Ray not to prosecute her in the travel office affair ''exonerated' her?     Some exoneration. We now have the full report of this e...
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember all the claims by Hillary Clinton's see-no-evil supporters that the decision by independent counsel Robert Ray not to prosecute her in the travel office affair ''exonerated' her? Some exoneration. We now have the full report of this egregious abuse of power and its six-year cover-up, and the evidence that she has been lying all along is damning.

docs.abstract: World Travel and Tourism Council study predicts Paris terror attack's impact on tourism will fade in time; finds that on average it takes about 13 months for tourism to recover after terror attack.
docs.snippet: An analysis of the impact of terrorist attacks on travel and tourism suggests that the long-term effect is more muted than after a natural disaster....
docs.lead_paragraph: An analysis of the impact of terrorist attacks on travel and tourism suggests that the long-term effect is more muted than after a natural disaster.

headline.main: Dip in Tourism After Most Attacks Is Short-Lived, Study Says
headline.print_headline: A Terror Attack’s Impact on Tourism Will Fade in Time, a Study Says

docs.abstract: In Transit blog; California-based travel company Mountain Travel Sobek offers 18-day trips to Chad, a little-visited African country.
